Device Usage and Its Impact on Students’ Academic Performance

In today’s world, technology has become an integral part of our lives. From smartphones to laptops and tablets, devices have become a necessity for many people. However, the use of devices in the classroom has become a topic of debate in recent years. Some argue that the presence of devices can help students to learn and engage more effectively, while others argue that it can distract them and lead to decreased academic performance.

Research has shown that the use of devices in the classroom can have both positive and negative effects on students’ academic performance. On one hand, devices can provide students with access to a wealth of information and resources, allowing them to learn and engage more effectively. On the other hand, devices can be a source of distraction, with students using them to browse social media, play games, or watch videos instead of focusing on the lesson.

There are many schools around the world that have implemented policies related to device usage in the classroom. Some schools have banned devices altogether, while others have allowed them with certain restrictions. For example, some schools have implemented a “no devices” policy during class time, while others have allowed students to use devices for educational purposes only.

The effectiveness of these policies varies. Some studies have shown that banning devices altogether can lead to increased academic performance, as students are forced to focus on the lesson without distractions. However, other studies have shown that allowing devices with restrictions can lead to increased engagement and improved academic performance.

Given the potential benefits and drawbacks of device usage in the classroom, it is important for schools to consider implementing strategies to mitigate the negative impact of devices on students’ academic performance. One potential strategy is to provide students with educational apps or software that can help them to learn and engage more effectively. Another strategy is to provide students with designated times during the day to use their devices for educational purposes, such as during study periods or after school.

In conclusion, the impact of device usage on students’ academic performance is a complex issue that requires careful consideration. While the use of devices in the classroom can have both positive and negative effects, schools must balance the benefits of technology with the need to ensure that students are focused and engaged during class time. By implementing effective policies and strategies, schools can help to ensure that students are able to benefit from technology while minimizing its potential negative impact

Let's be honest, sometimes people don't know what to do or who to talk to at times. Sometimes we as human beings make mistakes and don't know what decisions to make when we do happen to make a mistake. We panic, and we can't seem to think about what we could do in that type of situation. It gives us stress and worry. That is why people need advice from others.

People like teachers, parents, basically adults that can be trusted like priests, police officers, etc. give great advice. They have experience with a lot of things when it comes to stress, mistakes, and things we could do to work hard to not make the same mistake again. They also comfort us with support and care for our wellbeing when we often go through troubling times like bullying, friends, and the facts of life. Furthermore, they also know how hard it is to get good grades for some people and how terrifying the thought of school can be. Furthermore, they know that it can be a nightmare for some to stay awake, study at 12:00 midnight, drink Starbucks(maybe) and overall think about when the next test or SOL or exam will come next.

Again, let's be honest, people just loved to be listened to at times. Whenever someone listens to their advice, they think that person cares about what they have to say and what ideas they have. It's what most people enjoy happening to them including peers the exact same age as you. It gives some people a sense of purpose and empathy for your current situation. Even you want to be listened to don't you?

Most of the time, people could be going through the same situation as you or maybe worse, we may not know what's going on in their life. You're listening to their advice could save them from maybe hurting their body or worse. They might get bullied a lot and have little to no friends, but you're listening to their advice and an extension them as a whole could really save them and make them a lot happier. They could suffer a terrible and messed up life. Furthermore, they might have made the same choice as you and could have gotten a much worse consequence of of it.

Rut sometimes listening to other's advice could do us more harm than good. Sometimes it could get us in an even worse situation then we were in before, and it could screw us up a lot more. Sometimes the advice we get would make no sense whatsoever and make the person sound like they have no common sense at all. Sometimes the advice would seem great but then backfire in a horrible twisted way. Sometimes going with your gut would seem to work better. Either way in some cases it would be best to follow your own advice.

So yes, in most if not all cases, you should follow someone's advice whether it be friends, family, etc. It can really save you when you're in a pickle and help you make choices based of it. It can make someone feel special and needed. Furthermore, it can save someone who wants to hurt themselves and/or others and give someone a purpose. All in all, listening to someone else's advice could help everyone involved.

The electoral college is an institution that has always guided  the presidential elections. The electoral college is tradition and shouldn't be changed because it has balanced relegation of power within the states, there is almost always a definate winner, and it is able to hold a set timeline for the elections. The college has always been able to choose a president that is able to lead our country well, the electoral college is a representation of the people of the United States of America. As the president's constituents, we have the power to choose our leader, and they make it a little easier for us.

The electoral college takes into account the populations of each state within its calculations. This is why Wyoming has only three votes and Florida has twenty nine. It's nothing to complain about, because it's the same number of people each state has in both the Senate and the House of Representatives, meaning each state has at least three votes, decided by its population. This is not a very bad system because the states with huge populations have a bit of their power curbed by the number of electors. So if Wyoming increases its population, and Florida has its population decreased, one of the electors could be removed from Florida and added to Wyoming, balancing the scale of power between them. It's only fair for a populous state like Florida to have more electors anyway, there are many opinions that are yearning to be heard within the ginormous population, and there must be enough electors who can take it upon themselves to voice them. The Electoral College protects us from the probability of voting just because the candidate is from the same state. A majority of people will vote because of a close association with a candidate if the electoral college is abolished. This is why the electoral college only contains 538 people, because nobody wants millions of voters in California voting for the same candidate just because they are the Governor of California.

Due to the even amount of votes in the electoral college, there is a slight chance of a tie. However, with all but two states being part of the "winner-take-all" system, the chance of that happening are astronomically low. This is why swing states are so important to the canditates, they know that the chances of them winning the votes in the other party's states are almost impossible, so they must gather all of the votes they can from the states that are known for their swing-like tendencies. It also goes the other way, each candidate trusts that their own party's states will vote for them, so there is no need to waste the money and campaign. Unless its the primary elections, candidates don't typically campaign where they know that the votes are all but set in stone. It's like going grocery shopping, if you know that you are allergic to peanut butter and you already have all the jam you need, you will only go for the special bread that everybody fights for right? The candidates are the same, they don't go after what they already have and what they can't have, only what they might earn, or else it's just a waste of money, so nobody should be able to complain about a candidates campaigning.

A president has always been inaugrated on either January 20th or March 4th, to change that would be blasphemous to both the people and to the United States of America. So it is imperitive that the decision is made early, so that tradition and will not be broken. Contrary to popular belief, there is a set timeline that the election process goes through, and without the electoral college, it is highly possible and probable that the timeline will be broken. The election process is guided by this timeline, for example, voting starts on the second Thursday of the month of November every single time. The Electoral College is a huge part of this process also, and to destroy that would be heartbreaking for the nuerotics that can't stand any change in routine. If the Electoral College were to be abolished, and popular vote was to be instigated throughout the country, any semblance of a schedule would be torn away. Problems would spring up all over the place, and everything would all go to hell. Instead of recounts for counties, whole states would need recounts. If a populous state like Texas were to need a recount, never mind a week, a month wouldn't be enough time to recount it all perfectly. The government would be stuck without a leader, and worst case scenario, the United States of America could be put in a state of anarchy by the end of the decade. Then, we wouldn't be United anymore.

The Electoral College has been there from the beginning, and the without it the United States of America could be thrown into chaos. Traditions shouldn't be broken and the Electoral College represents the biggest one of them all, it balances power between each of the states, defines a true winner, and guides the U.S. on a set timeline. It wouldn't be a far stretch to say that the Electoral College helps keep the order of the country. Truthfully, everyone needs some semblance of order, and the Electoral College provides that and more.

What is more comforting than doing your schoolwork in the comfort of your own home. Virtual or online learning can be more beneficial to students than learning in a large classroom. Students would have less of a chance to fall behind because they have all of their information right in front of them. They can focus better by not having all the distractions they would in a large classroom. If a student doesnt understand something they have as much time as they need to work on the topic. Students would have a better opportunity to succeed by staying in tuned in a class all online.

At home the student could learn at their own pace and still have the help from their teacher, some students find it hard to learn with tons of people in one room because there tends to be more distractions, it could cause them to fall behind. Virtual learning could solve most of the problems lots of students have: missing a few days because of being sick, going on vacation, or maybe they just couldnt focus that day. The students could go home and catch up on everything they missed without being confused the next class.

Students can set up an easier environment for them to learn in, they could be in complete silence to focus better or maybe play some music while they do their work, while they might not be able to do that in a classroom. They also can take however long to do their work at their own pace. People may ask how a student can ask questions or go to someone when they need help, the student can email the teacher at anytime or if its virtual you can ask during the lesson.

All of your classes in a school day are all the same length of time, if you were learning online at home you could spend more time on subjects that are more challenging than others. Students would have more time to complete assignments because there is no time limit on learning online. Some students cant focus when they are hungry as well and have to wait till lunch to eat, when you are doing a virtual course you can get up and get a snack at anytime without missing anything.

Virtual and online learning gives students a better opportunity to learn more for however much time they need. I could understand how someone may thing online learning could allow students to find themselves doing other things instead of their school work, but most online programs have a select amount of work you have to do or you fail the class. When I first heard about the Seagoing Cowboys program, I was skeptical that a cowboy like me could handle bouncing around on the open seas. Most importantly, participating in the Seagoing Cowboys allowed me to indulge my sense of adventure while doing meaningful work. Shipping livestock between countries plays a crucial role in feeding communities worldwide. To play even a small part in that process, while also seeking thrills very different from ranch life, was deeply rewarding. I still can't wipe the grin off my face when I think back to braving rocky storms at sea or watching new lands come into view on the horizon. Any person with wanderlust in their soul would be foolish not to sign up. I hope this gives others the push they need to experience this incredible opportunity for themselves. Research has shown that eating a vegetarian or vegan diet can lead to improved physical health by reducing risk factors associated with chronic diseases such as obesity, type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, certain types of cancer, kidney disease and osteoporosis. A well-planned plant-based diet may also promote good mental health by improving mood states like depression or anxiety. Moreover, studies have found that eating fewer animal products reduces one's carbon footprint significantly since animal agriculture contributes heavily to greenhouse gas emissions compared to plant production systems which are much friendlier for the environment when managed properly. Furthermore, switching from conventional animal protein sources (such as beef) to ethically farmed alternatives not only helps reduce your ecological impact but also supports better welfare standards for livestock – something many vegans consider quite important when choosing food options. text:
Venus, also known as Earth's "sister planet", has fascinated scientists, astronomers, and curious individuals alike for many decades. Named after the Roman goddess of love, this second planet from the Sun is an intriguing celestial body with numerous mysteries yet to be unveiled. However, in the quest to explore this beautiful celestial entity, researchers face numerous hurdles due to the challenges it poses such as extreme heat, dense atmosphere, and difficulties in communication from Earth. With significant advancements in technology and scientific knowledge, we stand on the cusp of gaining deeper insight into Venus' various mysteries and making the most of its potential resources.

Venus and Earth are often considered cousins due to their striking similarities in size, composition, and proximity to the Sun, both within our solar system. However, their contrasting conditions demonstrate the fragility of Earth's biosphere. Venus' surface temperature, for instance, is known to reach over 450°C (842°F), the hottest environment any astronaut would experience. This extreme heat is a consequence of the greenhouse effect caused by the dense, sulfuric acid-laden atmosphere, which traps heat near its surface. Moreover, its atmospheric pressure is approximately 90 times greater than that on Earth, making it impossible for human life to survive. These factors illustrate why Mars, despite farther away, seemed a safer and potentially more habitable destination for future space exploration efforts.

Despite the harsh conditions on the surface of Venus, the planet's atmosphere has given rise to a unique and ever-evolving field of research – atmospheric science. While this field faces its own set of challenges, including poor weather prediction due to intense planetary rotation, atmospheric scientists have revealed vital details about Venus' atmospheric phenomena such as the notorious clouds, the sulfuric acid rain, winds, and global upheavals caused by planet-wide planetary waves. 

In recent times, technology has paved the way for remarkable leaps in our understandings of the enigmatic planet, Venus. Missions such as the European Space Agency's Venus Express Orbiter, which mapped the planet's atmosphere and surface with remarkable precision, and the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency's Akatsuki Orbiter, which furthered our knowledge of Venusian weather and planetary circulation, have been major stepping stones in our progress. NASA's Magellan, a radar mapper that detailed Venus' topographical landscapes and geological formations, and the American Venus Orbiter Program that successfully completed two flybys from orbit to collect valuable data on density and water vapor within its atmosphere, significantly expanded our knowledge of the planet's conditions.

Future endeavors to explore Venus include the development of new technologies and spacecraft capable of withstanding the extreme temperatures and pressures that characterize the planet's atmosphere. The United States' DAVINCI+ (Deep Atmosphere Venus Investigation of Noble gases, Chemistry, and Imaging Plus) mission, a planned orbiter scheduled for launch in the early 2030s, aims to not only sample the Venusian atmosphere but to also probe below the cloud cover for the first time. This mission would significantly advance our knowledge of the planet's interior, composition, and history of volcanism - all crucial elements in determining its habitability for earthly life.

Furthermore, researchers are actively discussing the possibility of using renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind power, to explore Venus under its extreme environmental conditions. This would require the application of innovative technologies like solar panel arrays that could generate power from the planet's harsh climate, opening new avenues of study for its possible energy resources.

Venus' rich mineral and volcanic resources are believed to contain vast reserves of aluminum, silicon, titanium, platinum metals, and rare earth elements, essential for advancing technologies such as consumer electronics, medical devices, and pharmaceutical products. While such extensive reserves present economic opportunities, potential developments must also consider the protection of the planet's delicate ecosystem, and the sustainable handling of extraction processes.

The exploration of Venus poses numerous challenges, but this should not discourage our efforts to understand and develop our knowledge of this fascinating celestial body. With innovative ideas, strategic planning, and continued advancements in technology and scientific understanding, we can undoubtedly unravel more secrets of Venus, its habitability, and the potential of its resources. As our ability to traverse the depths of space increases, so does our comprehension of the intricate relationship between celestial bodies such as Venus and our own Earth. The lessons brought forth through this understanding will be invaluable as we continue to strive for the betterment of all life in our solar system and beyond.

In today's society, competition is often seen as the key to success. However, when it comes to children, I firmly believe that they should be taught to cooperate rather than to compete. In this essay, I will explain why cooperation is important for children's development and why it'should be prioritized over competition.

Firstly, cooperation teaches children important social skills that will be useful throughout their lives. When children learn to work together, they develop communication, problem-solving, and negotiation skills. They learn to listen to others, share ideas, and compromise. These skills are essential for success in both personal and professional relationships. In contrast, competition can promote self-centeredness and a "win at all costs" mentality that can damage relationships and hinder collaboration in the long run.

Secondly, cooperation promotes a positive learning environment. In a cooperative classroom, children are encouraged to help each other and work together to achieve common goals. This fosters a sense of community and belonging, which can lead to increased motivation and engagement in learning. In contrast, a competitive classroom can create a stressful and hostile environment, where students are pitted against each other and are more concerned with outperforming their peers than with learning.

Finally, cooperation teaches children empathy and compassion. When children learn to work together, they are more likely to understand and appreciate the perspectives and feelings of others. They learn to be supportive and encouraging, rather than critical and judgmental. This can lead to better mental health and well-being, as well as stronger and more fulfilling relationships.

In conclusion, while competition may have it's place in certain contexts, I believe that cooperation should be the primary focus when it comes to children's education and development. By teaching children to work together, we can promote important social skills, create a positive learning environment, and cultivate empathy and compassion. These are essential qualities for a successful and fulfilling life, and they can only be developed through cooperation.

When faced with an important decision, it is wise to get perspectives from more than one person. Seeking advice from multiple sources has several benefits.

Firstly, different people will often see aspects of a situation from different angles. When we get only one opinion, we may fail to consider important factors since no one person thinks of everything. However, hearing multiple viewpoints helps ensure more sides of the issue are brought to light. For example, if trying to pick a university major, talking to a professor, career counselor, and parent all provides varied insights.  

Secondly, people sometimes give biased advice unintentionally based on their own experiences and priorities. Talking to just one advisor leaves us open to acting on a recommendation colored by that person's biases. But getting a range of opinions helps balance out these unconscious biases. We can identify common themes in the guidance while disregarding advice faulty or self-interested.

Finally, having a variety of perspectives increases the chances of hearing a genuinely useful suggestion. Not every advisor will have a silver bullet answer, but the more people we consult, the greater the odds are of uncovering an innovative or creative solution. For instance, if struggling to choose between two jobs, the friend who floated the idea of negotiating for a higher salary at one option could prove pivotal. 

In conclusion, seeking counsel from multiple trusted sources provides a well-rounded approach to decision making. It helps surface more information, mitigates individual biases, and multiplies our chances of finding an optimal choice. Therefore, whenever a consequential choice must be made, the smart path is to gather multiple opinions.
